revision_content.description: Master the fundamentals of number systems and mathematical operations

subtopics.title: Natural Numbers
subtopics.definition: These are the basic counting numbers that start from 1 and go on forever.
subtopics.whyItMatters: We use these numbers every day to count things like people, objects, or steps.
quickTips: Natural numbers do NOT include zero.
They’re always positive, never negative.

subtopics.title: Whole Numbers
subtopics.definition: These are natural numbers plus zero.
subtopics.whyItMatters: They’re useful in situations where having ‘nothing’ is still a valid answer, like a bank account with zero balance.
quickTips: 0 is the key difference between whole and natural numbers.
All natural numbers are also whole numbers.

subtopics.title: Integers
subtopics.definition: Integers include all whole numbers and their negative counterparts.
subtopics.whyItMatters: Integers are super important in real life like measuring temperature, altitude, or calculating losses.
quickTips: Negative × Negative = Positive
Use number lines to easily compare integers.

subtopics.title: Rational Numbers
subtopics.definition: Numbers that can be written as a fraction a/b, where b ≠ 0.
subtopics.whyItMatters: Useful in daily tasks like dealing with money, discounts, or recipes.
quickTips: All fractions and simple decimals are rational.
Repeating or ending decimals always mean rational numbers.

subtopics.title: Irrational Numbers
subtopics.definition: Numbers that cannot be written as simple fractions.

example.question: Is √2 irrational?
example.answer: Yes, because it doesn't end or repeat.

subtopics.whyItMatters: Often appears in geometry, like when calculating diagonals or circles (π).
quickTips: Examples: π, √2, √3
Their decimals go on forever without any pattern.

subtopics.title: Real Numbers
subtopics.definition: All numbers on the number line — includes both rational and irrational numbers.
subtopics.whyItMatters: Covers all types of numbers you’ll deal with in school and most of real life.
quickTips: If you can plot it on a number line, it’s a real number.

subtopics.title: Even and Odd Numbers
subtopics.definition: Even numbers can be divided by 2 exactly. Odd numbers can’t.
subtopics.whyItMatters: Important in patterns, puzzles, and grouping.
quickTips: Even: ends in 0, 2, 4, 6, 8
Odd: ends in 1, 3, 5, 7, 9

subtopics.title: Prime Numbers
subtopics.definition: Natural numbers greater than 1 that have only two factors: 1 and itself.
subtopics.whyItMatters: They are the building blocks of all numbers — just like atoms are in science.
quickTips: 2 is the only even prime number.
1 is NOT considered a prime number.

subtopics.title: Composite Numbers
subtopics.definition: Natural numbers greater than 1 that have more than two factors.
subtopics.whyItMatters: Used in factor trees and simplifying problems.
quickTips: If it’s not prime and has more than 2 factors, it’s composite.

subtopics.title: LCM (Least Common Multiple)
subtopics.definition: The smallest number that is a multiple of two or more numbers.
subtopics.whyItMatters: Helpful in working with fractions, timetables, or aligning schedules.
quickTips: Try listing multiples or use prime factorization to find it.

subtopics.title: HCF (Highest Common Factor)
subtopics.definition: The largest number that divides two or more numbers exactly.
subtopics.whyItMatters: Useful when reducing fractions to simplest form.
quickTips: Break numbers into prime factors or use the ladder method.

subtopics.title: Number Properties
subtopics.definition: Rules that explain how numbers behave under operations like addition and multiplication.

example.question: a + b = b + a is what property?

subtopics.whyItMatters: Makes it easier to solve, rearrange, and simplify equations.
quickTips: Commutative: order doesn’t matter
Associative: grouping doesn’t matter
Distributive: break it down to simplify

subtopics.title: BODMAS/BIDMAS
subtopics.definition: A rule for the correct order to solve maths problems with multiple operations.
subtopics.whyItMatters: Stops you from solving problems the wrong way and getting wrong answers.
quickTips: BODMAS = Brackets, Orders, Division/Multiplication, Addition/Subtraction
Do operations in this order, always.

subtopics.title: Scientific Notation
subtopics.definition: A way to write very large or very small numbers using powers of 10.
subtopics.whyItMatters: Makes it easier to work with big data in science, engineering, and space stuff.
quickTips: Number must be between 1 and 10 before ×10^n
Count how many places the decimal moves.

subtopics.title: Standard Form
subtopics.definition: Writing numbers normally, not in scientific notation.
subtopics.whyItMatters: This is the way we see and use numbers in real life.
quickTips: Just do the multiplication to convert back.

subtopics.title: Rounding and Estimation
subtopics.definition: Roughly adjusting a number to make calculations quicker or easier.
subtopics.whyItMatters: Makes life easier when exact answers aren't needed — like budgeting or travel time.
quickTips: Look at the digit after the place value to decide whether to round up or down.
